questions.text: Name the marked area?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The arcuate fasciculus is a bundle of association fibres connecting Broca's area (Brodmann areas 44 and 45) with Wernicke's area (area 22), critical for language processing. The image shows fibres arching between these areas, confirming it is the arcuate fasciculus.

  • Location & Function:
    • Connects the frontal lobe (Broca's area) to the temporal lobe (Wernicke’s area).
    • Involved in language repetition and comprehension.
    • Lesion leads to conduction aphasia (fluent speech with poor repetition).
  • Visual clue from image:
    • Area 44, 45 (Broca) → long curved fibre → Area 22 (Wernicke).
    • Typical path of the arcuate fasciculus.

Explanation of Other Options:

Lissauer's fasciculus (Option B): Found in the dorsolateral spinal cord; conveys pain and temperature fibres, not a cerebral association fibre.

Cuneate fasciculus (Option C): Ascending dorsal column tract for fine touch and proprioception from the upper limb. Located in the spinal cord and lower medulla.

Gracile fasciculus (Option D): Another dorsal column tract conveying fine touch and proprioception, but from the lower limbs, not related to cerebral hemispheric connections.

questions.text: Which artery supplies the marked structure shown below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The subcallosal artery, a branch of the anterior communicating artery, supplies the rostrum and genu of the corpus callosum, which is the structure marked in the image.

  • The posterior pericallosal (splenial) artery is usually a branch of the posterior cerebral artery and bifurcates into superior and inferior branches that supply the splenium, not the genu.
  • The subcallosal artery supplies both parts of the hypothalamus and the rostrum and genu of the corpus callosum.
  • The superior branch of the splenial artery often anastomoses with the pericallosal artery, which itself runs along the dorsal aspect of the corpus callosum and is a branch of the anterior cerebral artery (ACA).
  • The median callosal artery, also from the anterior communicating artery, may variably contribute to corpus callosum perfusion.

Explanation of Other Options:

Posterior cerebral artery (Option A): Gives rise to the posterior pericallosal (splenial) artery, which supplies the splenium, not the genu.

Median callosal artery (Option C): Can also supply the corpus callosum, but the subcallosal artery is more consistently involved in supplying the genu and rostrum.

Anterior cerebral artery (Option D): Gives rise to the pericallosal artery, which runs along the superior border of the corpus callosum but does not directly supply the genu.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a true arterial supply to the marked area?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The medial region marked C in the image represents an area supplied by medial lenticulostriate arteries, which arise from the anterior cerebral artery (ACA). The anterior choroidal artery, which arises from the internal carotid artery, typically supplies more lateral and posterior structures (e.g. posterior limb of internal capsule, optic tract), not this centrally located region.

(Other options ruled out)

choices.text: Provides interhemispheric connections between the temporal lobe brain regions.
Provides interhemispheric connections between parietal lobe brain regions.
Provides interhemispheric connections between frontal lobe brain regions.
Provides interhemispheric connections between the hippocampal lobe brain regions.

questions.text: What is the function of the commisure shown in the picture below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The commissure shown in the image is the dorsal hippocampal commissure (DHC), also called the commissure of the fornix, a white matter tract that interconnects the hippocampi across the midline.

  • Primary function: Connects temporal lobe structures, particularly the hippocampi of both cerebral hemispheres.
  • Despite the role of the hippocampus in learning and memory, the DHC itself has limited proven relevance in memory performance.
  • The fornix, arising from the hippocampus, splits into two crura posteriorly, which are joined across the midline by the DHC (commissure of fornix).
  • The DHC connects the crura of the fornix and thus interlinks the hippocampal formations bilaterally, enabling communication between the temporal lobes.

Explanation of Other Options:

Provides interhemispheric connections between parietal lobe brain regions (Option B): Incorrect; this is done mainly by fibres of the corpus callosum (e.g., superior longitudinal fasciculus).

Provides interhemispheric connections between frontal lobe brain regions (Option C): Incorrect; mainly through the anterior part of the corpus callosum (genu).

Provides interhemispheric connections between hippocampal lobe brain regions (Option D): Incorrect terminology; "hippocampal lobe" is not anatomically defined - hippocampi are in the temporal lobes.

questions.text: What fibres are given structure composed of?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The structure in question consists of a combination of association fibres and commissural fibres, which are two of the primary classifications of white matter tracts in the brain.

  • Association fibres: Connect cortical areas within the same hemisphere (e.g., superior longitudinal fasciculus, uncinate fasciculus).
  • Commissural fibres: Connect corresponding cortical areas between the two hemispheres (e.g., corpus callosum, anterior commissure).
  • White matter fasciculi can contain multiple fibre types, especially those connecting functionally related but anatomically distant regions.

Explanation of Other Options:

Projection fibre + Commissural fibre (Option A): Projection fibres connect the cortex with subcortical areas; not typically combined with commissural fibres in one tract.

Projection fibre + Association fibre (Option C): Seen in mixed tracts like the uncinate fasciculus, but not relevant here based on structure.

Association fibre + Corpus callosum (OptionD): Corpus callosum is a commissural fibre bundle, not a distinct fibre type; this is a classification error.

questions.text: Identify the fornix in the image below
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The fornix is a C-shaped white matter tract composed mainly of efferent fibres from the hippocampus, arching over the thalamus and under the corpus callosum. It is a major output pathway of the hippocampus and is correctly identified as the structure labelled C in the given image.

Explanation of Other Options:

B (Option A): Likely corresponds to the insula; involved in gustatory and visceral sensation, not part of the fornix.

A (Option B): Points to the hippocampus directly; though related, it is not the fornix itself.

D (Option D): Corresponds to the corpus callosum, a commissural fibre tract connecting the cerebral hemispheres, but not the fornix.

choices.text: A gate control exists by which peripheral afferents and descending pathways can modulate sensory transmission.
Involved in the transmission and modulation of pain, temperature, and touch.
Many cells are local interneurons and likely play an important role as inhibitory and excitatory interneurons that regulate local excitability.
The substantia gelatinosa of Rolando (SGR) is a white matter structure of the dorsal spinal cord.

questions.text: What is not true about the marked structure in the spinal cord cross-section?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The substantia gelatinosa of Rolando (SGR), marked in the image, is a gray matter structure located in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord. It is primarily involved in processing nociceptive inputs (pain, temperature, and crude touch).

  • (SGR) It is a grey matter structure of the dorsal spinal cord primarily involved in the transmission and modulation of pain, temperature, and touch. (Option C)
  • A gate control exists by which peripheral afferents and descending pathways can modulate sensory transmission. Evidence is presented that the mechanism may exist in the substantia gelatinosa laminae II and III (Option A)
  • The substantia gelatinosa contains numerous cell types.
  • Many cells are local interneurons and likely play an important role as inhibitory and excitatory interneurons that regulate local excitability; however, some of these cells clearly project rostrally. (Option B)

choices.text: The gracile and cuneate fasciculi, collectively called the anterior columns
Heavily myelinated primary sensory fibres that convey proprioceptive, tactile, and vibratory information from the ipsilateral side of the body
Heavily myelinated primary sensory fibres that convey proprioceptive, tactile, and vibratory information from the contralateral side of the body
Pain signals may also be transmitted via the anterior columns, especially the gracile fasciculus, from the pelvic viscera to the thalamus

questions.text: Identify the correct statement regarding the labelled structures A and B (Fasciculus gracilis and fasciculus cuneatus):
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The labelled structures A and B represent the posterior column tracts (gracile and cuneate fasciculi) of the spinal cord, which are composed of heavily myelinated primary sensory fibres. These fibres transmit conscious proprioception, discriminative touch, and vibration sense from the ipsilateral side of the body to the brainstem.

  • Label A (medial): Gracile fasciculus - conveys signals from lower limb and trunk (T6 and below).
  • Label B (lateral): Cuneate fasciculus - conveys signals from upper limb and trunk (above T6).
  • These fibres synapse in the nucleus gracilis and nucleus cuneatus in the medulla.
  • From there, second-order neurons decussate via internal arcuate fibres and form the medial lemniscus, projecting to the thalamus.
  • Injury to the posterior column on one side leads to loss of vibration, proprioception, and tactile sensation on the same (ipsilateral) side below the lesion.
  • Although the primary role is mechanosensory transmission, clinical evidence suggests that visceral pain signals from pelvic organs may also ascend via these tracts, especially the gracile fasciculus, via the postsynaptic posterior column system.
  • Despite this, these tracts are definitively classified under the posterior, not anterior, columns.

(Other Options are ruled out)

choices.text: Receives the spinothalamic tracts and the medial lemniscus
Lesion results in contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation and loss of tactile discrimination in the trunk and extremities
Projects to the somatosensory cortex (postcentral gyrus - areas 3, 1, and 2)
These projections pass through the putamen and corona radiata

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding the nucleus shown below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Ventral Posterolateral (VPL) nucleus of the thalamus is shown in the image. It:

  • Receives: Both the spinothalamic tract (pain & temperature) and the medial lemniscus (tactile discrimination, vibration, proprioception) from the contralateral side of the body. (Option A, B)
  • Projects to: Primary somatosensory cortex (postcentral gyrus - Brodmann areas 3, 1, 2). (Option C)
  • Projection pathway: Fibres travel through the posterior limb of the internal capsule and corona radiata, not through the putamen, which is a basal ganglia nucleus not involved in this sensory relay.
  • Lesion results in: Contralateral loss of fine touch, vibration, proprioception, and pain/temperature from the trunk and limbs.

questions.text: The marked structure of the brain is classified under
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The cingulum is a long association fibre that lies within the cingulate gyrus, forming a prominent component of the limbic system.

  • It connects the frontal, parietal, and cingulate cortical areas with the parahippocampal gyrus and temporal lobe
  • It runs longitudinally above the corpus callosum, arching around from the subcallosal area to the parahippocampal gyrus.
  • It forms part of the Papez circuit, which is important in emotion, memory, and autonomic integration.

Explanation of Other Options:

Short association fibres (Option B): These connect adjacent gyri within the same lobe, typically forming U-shaped fibres beneath the cortical surface; the cingulum spans multiple lobes and is much longer.

Commissural fibres (Option C): These interconnect corresponding cortical areas across hemispheres (e.g. corpus callosum, anterior commissure); the cingulum remains within one hemisphere.

Projection fibres (Option D): These connect the cerebral cortex with subcortical structures (e.g., internal capsule linking cortex to brainstem and spinal cord); the cingulum does not connect to subcortical targets.

questions.text: What is the origin of the fibres marked in the image shown below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The arrow indicates the fornix. It arises from the hippocampus and ends in the mamillary body of the hypothalamus.

  • Origin: The fornix arises from the hippocampus, specifically from the alveus and fimbria.
  • Course: It arches superiorly under the corpus callosum, forming the body and then divides into precommissural and postcommissural fibres at the anterior commissure.
  • Termination: It primarily terminates in the mamillary bodies of the hypothalamus.
  • Fornix is an example of an association fibre. It is supplied by the anterior cerebral artery.

Explanation of Other Options:

Amygdala (Option A): Part of the limbic system but projects via the stria terminalis, not the fornix.

Habenular (Option C): Receives input via the stria medullaris thalami, unrelated to the fornix origin.

Mamillary body (Option D): Terminus of postcommissural fornix, not the origin.

questions.text: Which of the following is connected to the structure marked as A in the image below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The structure marked A is the splenium of the corpus callosum, and it is connected to the striate cortex.

  • The body of the corpus callosum arches posteriorly and ends as the thickened posterior portion called the splenium. The fibres from the splenium form the forceps major and arch backwards into the occipital lobe (striate cortex).
  • The hippocampus is not connected directly to the splenium, but is situated inferior to the splenium.

Explanation of Other Options:

Orbital cortex (Option A): Connected via the genu of the corpus callosum through the forceps minor, not the splenium.

Hippocampus (Option B): Not directly connected to the splenium; instead, it is associated with the fornix, which arches beneath the corpus callosum.

Optic chiasma (Option D): Located anteroinferior to the corpus callosum and is not structurally connected to the splenium.

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of being unable to learn to perform new tasks that require interdependent movement of each hand. On examination, eye movements remain coordinated. His relatives noticed unusual behaviours concerning speech and object recognition. He is diagnosed with split-brain syndrome following an experimental brain surgery to manage severe epileptic seizures. Which fibres constitute the surgically resected structure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario of split-brain syndrome is a type of disconnection syndrome following corpus callosotomy. Commissural fibres constitute the surgically resected structure, i.e. the corpus callosum.

  • The corpus callosum connects homologous areas of the left and right cerebral hemispheres.
  • Resection causes loss of interhemispheric communication, especially affecting tasks requiring coordination between both hands.
  • Associated findings include:
    • Inability to perform bimanual tasks.
    • Speech and object recognition difficulties occur when sensory input is isolated to one hemisphere.

Explanation of Other Options:

Projection fibres (Option A): Connect cortex with subcortical centres (thalamus, spinal cord); not involved in interhemispheric transfer.

Short association fibres (Option C): Connect adjacent gyri within the same hemisphere; do not cross midline.

Long association fibres (Option D): Connect distant cortical areas within the same hemisphere (e.g., fronto-occipital); remain ipsilateral.

questions.text: A patient presented with self-inflicted injuries, auditory hallucinations and delusions. MRI revealed a tumour involving the posterior limb of the internal capsule and the structure medial to it. Which structure is likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

B is the Thalamus. The given clinical scenario is suggestive of tumour-associated psychosis. The thalamus lies medial to the posterior limb of the internal capsule and is most likely to be affected in this patient.

  • The internal capsule separates the thalamus and the caudate nucleus from the lentiform nucleus (globus pallidus + putamen).
  • It is V-shaped in horizontal section and is divided into the anterior limb, genu, posterior limb, retrolenticular part, and sublenticular part.
  • The anterior limb is located between the head of the caudate nucleus medially and the lentiform nucleus laterally.
  • The posterior limb is located between the thalamus medially and the lentiform nucleus laterally.

Explanation of Other Options:

D (Option B): Pons; part of the brainstem located caudal to the midbrain, involved in basic life functions and not adjacent to the posterior limb of the internal capsule.

A (Option C): Third ventricle; a midline CSF-filled cavity between thalamic masses, not directly involved in relay pathways or behavioural modulation.

C (Option D): Midbrain; although superior to the pons and near the thalamus, it is not in direct relation to the posterior limb of the internal capsule in the coronal plane.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presented with dysarthria suggestive of a lesion involving the internal capsule. MRI revealed an ischemic stroke. Which parts of the internal capsule were most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A is the genu of the internal capsule, the site where corticonuclear (corticobulbar) fibres descend from the motor cortex to brainstem cranial nerve nuclei, making it the most likely structure affected in this patient.

  • The majority of corticonuclear fibres cross in the median plane before supplying the cranial nerve nuclei.
  • All cranial motor nuclei receive bilateral corticonuclear connections except, facial nucleus, which supplies the lower part of the face, and the hypoglossal nucleus, which supplies the genioglossus muscle.
  • Hence, a lesion of these fibres causes contralateral clinical manifestations.

Explanation of Other Options:

D (Option B): Auditory radiation; involved in the transmission of auditory information from the medial geniculate body to the auditory cortex, not involved in speech motor control.

C (Option C): Posterior limb of internal capsule; contains corticospinal fibres for limb and trunk, but not the corticonuclear fibres responsible for cranial nerve innervation.

B (Option D): Thalamocortical fibres; these are ascending sensory projection fibres, unrelated to motor speech control.

questions.text: The habenular commissure is located in the
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The habenular commissure is a small bundle of commissural fibres connecting the habenular nuclei across the midline and is situated in the superior lamina of the pineal gland.

The locations of the commissural fibres are:

  • Corpus callosum- Medial surface of the brain
  • Anterior commissure- Beneath the rostrum of the corpus callosum
  • Posterior commissure- In the inferior lamina of the pineal gland
  • Habenular commissure- In the superior lamina of the pineal gland
  • Hippocampal commissure- Between the right fornix and the left fornix

Explanation of Other Options:

Splenium of corpus callosum (Option A): Refers to the posterior portion of the corpus callosum, which contains callosal fibres connecting occipital lobes but does not contain the habenular commissure.

Inferior lamina of pineal gland (Option C): Contains the posterior commissure, not the habenular commissure.

Lamina terminalis (Option D): A thin membrane located anterior to the third ventricle and forms the anterior wall of the third ventricle; associated with the anterior commissure, not the habenular commissure.

questions.text: Match the following commissural fibres with the structures they connect:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct matches are based on the anatomical connections of the major commissural fibres:

  • These fibres are located in different regions of the diencephalon and telencephalon.
  • Each serves an essential role in interhemispheric communication across specific functional domains.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with the inability to form words but can make noises. He also knows what he wants to say. What area of the brain has been damaged in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical features described indicate expressive aphasia (Broca's aphasia), which is due to damage in Broca's area, located in the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere.

  • In Broca's aphasia/ Motor aphasia / Non-fluent aphasia, areas 44 and 45 in the prefrontal and premotor facial regions of the cerebral cortex are affected.
  • The affected individuals will have difficulty forming verbal or written words. The comprehension aspect of speech is preserved, but the person cannot repeat or name the words and lacks fluency.
  • Patients in whom the area is severely affected may have very few words to express all of their emotions.

Explanation of Other Options:

Wernicke’s area (Option A): Located in the superior temporal gyrus; responsible for language comprehension. Damage leads to receptive aphasia, where speech is fluent but meaningless, and comprehension is impaired.

Heschl’s gyrus (Option C): Location of the primary auditory cortex; involved in processing sound, not language production. Lesions affect hearing perception, not expressive speech.

Striate area (Option D): Corresponds to the primary visual cortex (area 17) in the occipital lobe; involved in vision, not speech or language.

questions.text: A patient presents with a speech abnormality following a hemorrhagic stroke. He does not understand any written words or conversation. His speech is fluent, but is incomprehensible. Repetition is also impaired. Where is the lesion located?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This clinical presentation is diagnostic of Wernicke's aphasia, a fluent aphasia characterised by:

  • Impaired comprehension of spoken and written language
  • Fluent but meaningless speech (e.g., paraphasias)
  • Impaired repetition of words or phrases

The lesion lies in Wernicke's area (labelled as B in the image), situated in the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus, in the dominant hemisphere. This region is vital for language comprehension.

  • The arcuate fasciculus, an association fibre, connects Wernicke's area with Broca's area. Lesion here may also cause conduction aphasia if selectively involved.

Explanation of Other Options:

C (Option B): Corresponds to the primary motor cortex, involved in voluntary motor control of the body and face; not involved in language comprehension or fluent speech production.

D (Option C): Corresponds to the auditory cortex, which is responsible for the perception of sound. Its lesion leads to auditory agnosia, not aphasia.

A (Option D): Corresponds to Broca's area, whose lesion results in non-fluent aphasia, characterised by effortful, broken speech but relatively intact comprehension.

questions.text: A patient underwent third ventriculostomy for treatment of hydrocephalus. During the procedure, the doctor accidentally perforated the floor of the third ventricle. Which of the following structures is not likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The oculomotor nerve is least likely to be injured during perforation of the floor of the third ventricle.

  • The oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III) does not form a part of the ventricular floor. Instead, it emerges from the midbrain ventrally at the level of the interpeduncular fossa, posterior and inferior to the mamillary bodies.
  • The structures related to the floor of the third ventricle (from anterior to posterior) include:
    1. Optic chiasma (Option D)
    2. Infundibulum (Option C)
    3. Mamillary bodies (Option A)
    4. Posterior perforating substance
    5. Tegmentum of the midbrain.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed to have an aneurysmal malformation of a vessel located in the quadrigeminal cistern. Identify the marked vessel present in it.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The quadrigeminal cistern contains the great cerebral vein of Galen.

  • The great cerebral vein of Galen is formed by the union of the internal cerebral veins posterior to the midbrain and anterior to the pineal gland.
  • It then joins the inferior sagittal sinus to form the straight sinus, which is part of the confluence of sinuses.
  • Malformation (aneurysmal dilatation) of this vein is a congenital condition associated with persistence of the embryonic prosencephalic vein of Markowski.
  • Such malformations may cause hydrocephalus or high-output cardiac failure in neonates.

questions.text: What structure is not a part of the epithalamus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The tuber cinereum is not part of the epithalamus; it belongs to the hypothalamus, forming the floor of the third ventricle and is involved in pituitary regulation.

  • The epithalamus includes structures located at the dorsomedial aspect of the diencephalon, involved in limbic and neuroendocrine integration.

questions.text: An MRI of the coronal section of the brain is given to you. Which of the following nuclei of the marked structure does not project to the neocortex?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The marked structure is the thalamus. The reticular nucleus of the thalamus does not project to the neocortex. Its output is mainly to the other thalamic nuclei. All other thalamic nuclei send output to the neocortex.

Explanation of Other Options:

Intralaminar nuclei (Option A): Project diffusely to the cortex and basal ganglia; involved in alertness and arousal.

Pulvinar nuclei (Option B): Project to parietal, occipital, and temporal cortex; involved in sensory integration.

Midline nuclei (Option D): Project to limbic cortex and prefrontal areas; role in emotional processing.

choices.text: Foramina of Luschka are the lateral openings
The floor is formed by the cerebellar hemispheres and superior vermis
Inferior medullary velum is composed of grey matter
The foramen of Magendie is a central aperture that pierces the superior medullary velum

questions.text: The T2-weighted MRI of a child is given below. Which of the following is true about the ventricle primarily involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The MRI shows a Dandy-Walker malformation. The Foramina of Luschka are the lateral outlets of the fourth ventricle, draining cerebrospinal fluid into the subarachnoid space, especially via the lateral recesses.

Dandy-Walker malformation (DWM) is a congenital anomaly involving cystic dilatation of the fourth ventricle, vermian hypoplasia, and expansion of the posterior fossa. It is characterised by:

  • Cystic enlargement of the fourth ventricle communicating with a posterior fossa cyst
  • Agenesis or hypoplasia of the cerebellar vermis
  • Elevation of the tentorium and torcula

The fourth ventricle, primarily involved in DWM, has the following anatomical features:

Explanation of Other Options:

The floor is formed by cerebellar hemispheres and superior vermis (Option B): The floor is formed by the rhomboid fossa, not cerebellar structures.

Inferior medullary velum is composed of grey matter (Option C): It is a thin lamina of white matter, not grey.

Foramen of Magendie pierces superior medullary velum (Option D): It pierces the inferior medullary velum, not the superior.

Reference:

Dandy Walker Malformation: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK538197/

choices.text: Fibres from the facial nerve, which cover the facial nucleus
Fibers from the facial nerve which cover the abducent nucleus

questions.text: Imaging done in a 66-year-old man with a suspected brainstem infarct showed a lesion at the facial colliculus. Which of the following structures are present here?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The facial colliculus is formed by the internal genu of the facial nerve, which loops dorsally over the abducent nucleus.

Explanation of Other Options:

Facial nerve nucleus (Option A): Located anterolateral to the abducent nucleus; not part of the collicular elevation.

Abducent nerve nucleus (Option B): Present deep to the colliculus, but it is not the superficial structure forming the elevation.

Fibres from the facial nerve, which cover the facial nucleus (Option C): Facial fibres loop over the abducent, not over their own nucleus.

questions.text: Identify the marked area A?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The area marked A is the hypoglossal triangle, which lies in the medial part of the medullary floor of the fourth ventricle and corresponds to the underlying hypoglossal nucleus.

  • The hypoglossal triangle is bounded laterally by the sulcus limitans and lies medial to the vagal and vestibular triangles.
  • It overlies the motor nucleus of the hypoglossal nerve (cranial nerve XII).
  • In the provided diagram, B corresponds to the vestibular triangle (more lateral, related to vestibular nuclei) and C to the vagal triangle (inferolateral, overlying dorsal motor nucleus of the vagus).

Explanation of Other Options:

Vestibular triangle (Option B): Lateral to the vagal triangle; overlies the vestibular nuclei, which are involved in balance and spatial orientation. This is marked as B in the image.

Vagal triangle (Option C): Lies between the hypoglossal and vestibular triangles; produced by the underlying dorsal motor nucleus of the vagus nerve (CN X). This is marked as C in the image.

Facial colliculus (Option D): Located in the pontine part of the floor of the fourth ventricle (not the medullary part as shown here); it is formed by fibres of the facial nerve looping over the abducent nucleus.
